title: Subinterval
text: The first step is to divide the interval from $$0$$ to $$2$$ into $$n$$ equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.
speech: The first step is to divide the interval from , 0  to  2  into  n  equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.

to   2
into   n
equal subintervals. These subintervals can be seen as rectangles.

title: Subinterval
text: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?

subHints.title: Subinterval
subHints.text: Since $$n=4$$ is given in this problem, we can divide the interval from $$x=0$$ to $$x=2$$ into $$4$$ rectangles.\n##figure1.gif##

speech: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?
pacedSpeech: How many subinterval or rectangle can we create in this problem?

title: Find the step size
text: The step size or width of the rectangles can be found using $$Δx=\frac{b-a}{n}$$ where $$b$$ is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and $$n$$ is the number of rectangles.
speech: The step size or width of the rectangles can be found using    delta x, is equal to fraction, b minus a, over n,   where  b  is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and  n  is the number of rectangles.

where   b
is the upper bound, a is the lower bound and   n
is the number of rectangles.

title: Find the step size
text: What is the upper bound of the interval?

title: Find the step size
text: For the $$4$$ rectangles, each rectangle has a width of $$Δx=\frac{2-0}{4}=0.5$$
speech: For the  4  rectangles, each rectangle has a width of    delta x is equal to, fraction, 2 minus 0, over 4,  is equal to 0.5

rectangles, each rectangle has a width of     delta x is equal to, fraction, 2 minus 0, over 4,  is equal to 0.5

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: We begin with the first rectangle whose starting point of $$x=0$$ and a width of $$0.5$$. The rectangle will end at the point $$x=0.5$$ and that endpoint of the current rectangle is also the starting point of the next rectangle.
speech: We begin with the first rectangle whose starting point of  x is equal to, 0  and a width of  0.5 . The rectangle will end at the point  x is equal to 0.5  and that endpoint of the current rectangle is also the starting point of the next rectangle.

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: Express in interval notation, what are the starting and ending points of the 3rd rectangle?
speech: Express in interval notation, what are the starting and ending points of the 3rd rectangle?

title: Find the start and end points of each rectangle
text: Continuing the process, we obtain $$4$$ intervals which are $$[0, 0.5], [0.5, 1], [1, 1.5]$$ and $$[1.5, 2]$$.
speech: Continuing the process, we obtain  4  intervals which are  the closed interval from 0 to 0.5 comma the closed interval from 0.5 to 1, comma the closed interval from 1 to 1.5,  and  the closed interval from 1.5 to 2 .

and   the closed interval from 1.5 to 2

title: Left-endpoint approximation
text: The left rectangle approximation is when you make the left hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the left endpoint of its base.
speech: The left rectangle approximation is when you make the left hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the left endpoint of its base.
pacedSpeech: The left rectangle approximation is when you make the left hand points of the pieces the height of the rectangles. In other words, the height of each rectangle is equal to the value of the function at the left endpoint of its base.

title: Left-endpoint approximation
text: Using the left-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval $$[0.5, 1]$$ ?
speech: Using the left-endpoint approximation, what is the height of a rectangle in the interval  the closed interval from 0.5 to 1  ?

title: Left-endpoint approximation
text: Using a left-endpoint approximation, the heights are $$f(0)=0, f(0.5)=0.25, f(1)=1, f(1.5)=2.25$$

title: Find the area of the rectangles
text: With the width and height just found, we can easily find the area of each rectangle using area of a rectangle formula $$A=w h$$ then add all of them up to get an approximation for the area under the curve.
speech: With the width and height just found, we can easily find the area of each rectangle using area of a rectangle formula ,   a is equal to w h  then add all of them up to get an approximation for the area under the curve.
